In comparison to Snowrunner, some improvements, other things are disappointing.  Overall it is far less challenging, and forgiving but still maintains some element of satisfaction that Snowrunner delivered.  It is a very different game, although having many things in common with its predecessor.

Cons

- No fuel
- No damage
- No vehicle customisation
- No trailer selection
- Cargo does not auto-load, tediously requires a crane to load unless you can luckily get cargos to spawn over the trailer bed
- Crane controls/vehicle controls are tremendously poorly designed
- Where the heck is the gear selection! automatic heavy machinery is boring and lacks sophistication
- Very limited vehicle selection
- There are straight-up discrepancies in the game everywhere, ie. tooltips stating that tradable loot is green when it is in fact yellow, a location called "Lorem Ipsum" in Deluge.
- Vehicles still woefully underpowered
- HUD and UI difficult to navigate and poorly explained early game

Despite all this, I find the game overall enjoyable and would recommend it because:

Pros

- Better physics
- Less tipping over
- Forgiving gameplay; no more snagging on indestructable tree trunks or branches made of the worlds best elastic
- I like the "story-ness" of the game
- Non-linear problem solving
- Vehicles automatically available for the next map, ie don't have to collect them all back in to spawn them in the next map.
- Maps are well thought out, and the biggest pro; can be improved by infrastructure which is often what I wished Snow runner had, particularly for those frequently used main roads.

Its worth getting, just don't expect it to be an updated version of Snowrunner, because its not and requires adjustment in your play style.

The only issue with this game is that people expected it to be Snowrunners/Mudrunners plus some new features.  It's not.  It is a different game with a different style, different objectives, and ultimately a different way of playing.  The fact that you drive vehicles in both is a common trait, but does not make them the same type of game any more than GTA is the same type of game as Forza, or Battlefield 6 is the same as an RTS.  

This game is about building infrastructure, such as repairing roads, clearing obstacles, building bridges, etc... the purpose is to create routes that NPC vehicles can navigate without your assistance.  It's a different type of challenge and a different playstyle.

That being said, it's a great game, you just need to know what you are getting into and not enter it with false assumptions based on other games you've played from the same developer that had the same visual style.

Roadcraft was not for me.

Having played and enjoyed a lot of Mud/Snowrunner, I was excited to see what looked like a more involved construction game from the same developers. While Snowrunner's bones are identifiably here, what you get is a dramatically watered down version of SnowRunner's offroading that seems to be intended for players who want a more casual and less involved experience. The customization and upgrade system from the previous games is completely absent from Roadcraft. There is no attachment or sense of progression to the vehicles. 

The virtual joystick controls used for the cranes and heavy equipment when playing with a mouse and keyboard are inexcusably bad. The devs didn't even try, and the game plays likw a poor console port in that regard. This is not a game to play without a controller.

But what was arguably the most aggravating experience in my two hours of gameplay was the convoy system. Plot a route on the map and AI driven trucks will populate it, giving you idle rewards. It's a cute idea for sure, intended to populate the map and make the game feel alive.

Let me tell you, it doesn't feel alive at all. The AI are incredibly basic and don't respond at all to the player, obstacles, or other vehicles. This game has earned three distinctions: my first review, my first pre-order, and my first (attempted) refund.

It can be best described by one word: gimmick.

All the challenge and variation of Snowrunner has been exchanged for the gimmick of being able to make your own roads and bridges.

In Snowrunner, I was happy to spend an hour making six feet of progress in a mud pit or dealing with a damaged truck, because I enjoyed the challenge (and realism).

In Roadcraft, I am greeted by truck parkour, invincible trucks, and custom roads and bridges that are pointless if you have sand (and don’t even look good).

At time of writing this, I have 162 hours of Snowrunner, have completed the base game solo, and have bought several DLC.

I have exactly 116 minutes of Roadcraft and was underwhelmed and disappointed by every second.

The Roadcraft demo was more enjoyable than the game itself ended up being, and I played the whole demo with no audio because of a computer issue.

I pre-ordered this as a birthday present to myself. One of the most disappointing presents I have gotten. Never even got to use any of the pre-order bonus either.

Not worth the time or money.

Nearly every aspect of this game is worse that Snowrunner. I get that the claim it's not supposed to be a Snowrunner clone, but it very much is. The vehicle customization has been completely removed. That by itself isn't a big deal, but now every vehicle is a single-purpose vehicle (at least the ones I've unlocked.) The only potentially dual-purpose is the cargo truck with crane. Almost, if not all, vehicles are generic trucks that somewhat resemble real vehicles, but not really. I don't really care all that much about that, it's just yet another area that is a step down from Snowrunner. There's less maps than Snowrunner, and less vehicles. I'm sure I'm overlooking a lot. 

So what's good? Some of the new mechanics. Being able to interact with the environment more is a nice addition, as well as missions that are more than just hauling cargo. In that aspect, it's a nice change from Snowrunner. Being able to build roads and bridges is fantastic. 

Overall, it's just meh. It's not "bad" but it's a little dull. Because of the simplified vehicle handling, there's not really any issues with getting stuck, even with the recently added difficulty settings. It really feels like it was made by a completely different company as a knock-off to Snowrunner. The overall feel is just one of lesser quality. I really wish I hadn't purchased it. I'm neutral to negative about RoadCraft. It's like a watered down Snow/Mudrunner. The "manual" gearbox isn't even manual, it still has the same terrible (automatic) shifting patterns and the only thing it does do is give you a high gear. The dedicated reverse is weird, all it does is prevent you from going forward. Right trigger is the gas and left trigger should act as a brake, but it doesn't and will rev up the engine for some reason. Logging is very hit or miss, half the time selecting a tree doesn't work and when it does, every five or so trees are made out of lead and topple the tree harvester.  Multiplayer is broken. The guests suffer from awful performance, network bugs, and camera glitches. Desync is common.

The best way to describe this game in one word is "almost". It almost works. The mechanics are right there, my fingertips are just barely brushing them, but alas, I can only almost reach them. You can drive the same route nine times and the tenth time results in your truck bouncing off a rock into the stratosphere.

Really the only good things are the terrain deformation and how that gives the player the opportunity to create things to do. In Snowrunner, you get the tasks and that's it. In this, you could fill in a pond or build a highway. If you are able to work around the weirdness and can make tasks for yourself, it might be worth $30, so only at a discounted price.

Bottom line is I feel like this should be listed as Early Access. To me, RoadCraft is not in an acceptable state to sell as a "working" game because there are just too many things that don't work quite like they should.

In theory, this is the game I wanted after playing SnowRunner and wishing I could build my own damn bridge.
In execution, this game falls short of SnowRunner in many ways.

The handling model has been changed for the worse across the board - I constantly found myself getting stuck in odd places and generally just not vibing with driving any of the vehicles. In SC, I'd get stuck, look at the terrain, and go "yeah, that makes sense". Here, it's almost random at times. This is not helped by the stubborn delivery caravan AI, which seems to delight in finding the one rock left on the path and fully shoving their tires into it.

Bizarre control schemes for cranes and other tools have returned, and it is still a nuisance to do anything other than the most basic of tasks. It is not fun having to switch between 3 different specialized vehicles, all with slightly different control schemes. I tried both keyboard and controller - neither felt quite right.

There are a whole slew of inconsistent and/or poorly thought out design decisions here, too (why are roads so narrow by default? why does the dump truck handle like [i]that[/i]? why is there no damage model for the vehicles? why do certain maps refuse to give you sand?). With all of these issues piled together, you get a game that seems to resist being played at every turn, while also being caught in the middle of an identity crisis - not quite a sim, but not a pick-up-and-play casual title, either. 

To stay within the series' theming, what should be a sandbox has turned into a tar pit, and I'm getting stuck on every single pebble on the way in. I can't say I didn't enjoy this game at all, though - there are some interesting ideas here, and it is ultimately satisfying to turn a muddy dirt path into a fully paved road, but there are so many little nitpicks along the way that really suck the joy out of the experience. Everything is just SO finicky to control and do.

tldr; This is not the Death Stranding of truckin' games, sadly, and I wish it were.

Update:  I did find that it runs on low settings on my steam deck, maybe with some optimization it could run as well as Snow runner does on the deck.

If you enjoy grinding for supplies, building roads and bridges, and scavenging through forests, this game can be a lot of fun. The graphics are solid, the physics feel slightly improved, and the maps and environments are well-designed.

I know this isn’t SnowRunner, MudRunner, or Expedition, so before anyone tells me to go play those, I get it. But one of the biggest reasons I loved those games was the strong modding community behind them. Mods made up at least half the fun for me. So when I saw mod support in this game’s menu, I was genuinely excited to see what the community would come up with, especially since the game already had the groundwork for road-building and environmental changes.

Unfortunately, about a week in, it became clear that the developers made it unnecessarily difficult to mod vehicles. Instead, they seem to only support map mods. That was disappointing. After the first three maps, everything starts to feel the same. It’s hard to get vehicles stuck, leveling roads properly is nearly impossible, and the largest dump truck in the game just scatters sand randomly on your level roads. There’s also very limited vehicle customization, just changing a color that applies to all vehicles.

Saber’s response to modding limitations has basically been, “Go play SnowRunner.”

it feels like they’ve intentionally restricted vehicle modding to push people toward buying DLC for new vehicles. Their first DLC included four vehicles and two map, one of which is just a base jeep with gear strapped on for hard mode, one is a long-bed truck that looks like a vehicle the ai already had, and two are bridge layers. Not worth $15 in my opinion.

Hard mode was added in a later update, but if you want to change any settings, you have to start a new company meaning you lose all progress. I had to use a save editor just to re-enable manual gear shifting.

You can check out other comments or Google RoadCraft mods, but I’d say if you liked SnowRunner or MudRunner, and also enjoy building and shaping your environment, you’ll probably have a good 40–60 hours of fun here, especially with friends.

Overall, it’s a decent sandbox to mess around in for a while. But without strong modding support, especially for vehicles, the game ends up feeling limited. I’m just disappointed to see a shift away from the modding community that made past titles so fun to me.

I was able to play for a short while before joining a friend’s multiplayer session, where the same issue occurred: a major frame rate drop that eventually resolved itself.

My system far exceeds the recommended requirements (RTX 4070 Ti Super, AMD Ryzen 7 9800X3D, 64GB RAM DDS5, wired 1.5 Gbps internet connection), so hardware limitations are not the cause. After reading reviews and Reddit threads, it's clear that I’m not the only one experiencing these performance problems.

While Roadcraft is a fun and promising game, the current performance issues make it unplayable for me. I’m disappointed considering the amount I spent, and the entertainment I was having. At this time I cannot recommend this game as the optimisation is so poor.
fun game but unplayable constant crashing makes it no worth buying

It's great fun up until you hit max level and unlock the mobile base, then if you use it, it removes all of the challenge from the game, if you don't use it, its always in the back of your mind that you could use it. The game doesn't live up to the "standard" set by the Mudrunner franchise, even though it's misleadingly marketed as a "Mudrunner game".

"Kelly" keeps force feeding you with unfunny jokey dialogue, that is AI generated instead of voice acted. Dialogue lacks any kind of emotion and punctuation and ends up just being soul crushingly cringy.
UI on the map just isn't intuitive and figuring out the mission objectives is unnecessarily hard. To remedy this, the developers chose to bombard the players screen constanly with casino-add-tier pop-up messages with overly explained directions. 
It's impossible to change the controller scheme freely, instead you're stuck with 4 presets, none of which even remotely reminds of the past mudrunner schemes. 
Camera movement is clonky instead of the smooth free flowing as in the older titles.

Over all, the whole game feels like a complete AI generated slop instead of a passion project like the earlier titles and lacks any kind of feel or atmosphere of the past titles.

I just can't with the steering and camera mechanics. It feels so unnatural; why must they be different, I feel I would've really enjoyed the game otherwise. No clutch either and there is only 2 gears, Low and High.

Am going to refund.

I like the game for its idea and performance. However, as someone who enjoys Snow Runner, I feel disappointed that fuel and repairs have been removed. I understand why they did this; it was more to do with the difference in game mechanics, but it is starting to lose focus of the original game. The primary concerns I have are with Kelly and her writing. As someone who has worked in a toxic work environment, what she brings up is a little annoying to hear, and I don't want to listen to it while relaxing. Her voice is pleasant, but that's all I have nice to say about her. I have turned off the radio voice message; I wish I could turn off the subtitles as well.

What could have been an incredible addition to the mud/snow runner series of games ends up falling flat. I was hoping it would be Snowrunner with a new infrastructure building mechanic to help you traverse terrain, but all it does is remove the best parts of Snowrunner and implement a half baked road building system which is clunky and frustrating. The gear box interface from Snowrunner is gone, replaced by an unintuitive button pressing system. Missions are repetitive, and the AI truck pathing leaves much to be desired. The game feels as though it has been designed to be played by ages 10 and below in all aspects. I have gone back to playing Snowrunner, which is the better game and I would refund Roadcraft if I was able.
While the concept and game play seemed good, the connection for coop was unfortunately abysmal. Cannot recommend if you plan on playing with other people.
Focus on Snowrunner by adding in new features, instead of this. Please.

First of all, THANK YOU SO MUCH to the STEAM support for refunding the game after 3 hrs of logged time.
I actually only played for 30 minutes and spent 2.5 hrs trying to figure out how to make a steering wheel, pedals and a joystick work and just didn't realise HOW BAD the controller support and key mapping in this game is. 
The expansion looked good, I love the content ideas, but it just isn't playable outside from keyboard, mouse and a game controller, xbox style. For anyone looking for a experience to operate heavy machinery with simulator controls, this is NOT for you. Even the extreme delay switching from keyboard to steering wheel breaks the controls and you can end up down the cliff, as your accelerator gets stuck or steering doesn't kick in. You have to smash buttons to make one or the other work and YES I have JoytoKey and know how to use it and it just does not help in this game, because the hydraulic controls are limited to a inflated control scheme.
The fact that we have these games in 2025 is very disappointing and all I can say is, Farming Simulator 19+ is a much better operator friendly experience. 
When they drop an update and reviews confirm improved support for multiple controllers, I will definitely purchase the game again. As for now, no thanks.
